results.question: How does a non-employee director receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant?
gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response: As a non-employee director, you have the option of receiving a grant of stock options or restricted stock units by the Board of Directors. You are not obligated to receive a grant or a stock option, but if you do receive a grant, you may receive a grant of stock options or restricted stock units as a result of your employment as a director.
results.csv_string_response:
A non-employee director will receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant on the date of his/her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
Annual option grants and restricted stock unit awards (or any pro-rated grants for directors initially appointed between annual meetings) vest on the earlier to occur of the first anniversary of the date of grant or the next annual meeting of stockholders. No portion of an option automatically granted to a director is exercisable after the tenth anniversary after the date of option grant. Additionally, an option automatically granted to a director may be exercisable after the termination of the director’s services as described in the option agreement, generally ending three months after such termination.
results.json_rows_response: The director’s pro-rated restricted stock unit award or option grant is exercisable within a year following the date of the grant. For purposes of this Form 10-K, the date of grant or option grant is the date of grant or option grant that is the earliest date on which the director was eligible to receive a restricted stock unit award or option grant.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.

results.csv_string_response: Net income (loss) per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
results.json_rows_response: The basic earnings per share, or EPS, is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. • Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending at BCE of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at BCE of $6 million in 2019, compared to last year, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
